 The concept of reincarnation makes more sense to me than the Christian notion wherein you go around once after which you face either eternal bliss or eternal damnation. It seems to me that such a notion violates two of the attributes which we generally ascribe to God, namely, mercy and justice. 
 
 
"It is appointed for man to die ONCE, and after that face judgment.." Hebrews 9:27

 
 That's a mighty fine verse, EZ, and it expresses an opinion.

The concept of reincarnation makes more sense to me than the Christian notion wherein you go around once after which you face either eternal bliss or eternal damnation. It seems to me that such a notion violates two of the attributes which we generally ascribe to God, namely, mercy and justice.

 
 And just how merciful is it to spend 1,000 generations going through the hell people go through on earth? If reincarnation is supposed to breed better people over the eons by virtue of them attaining a higher level of understanding, compassion, etc., through Karma, then it isn't working. All we see is that the more man "evolves" (according to your view), the more efficient he becomes at exterminating his fellow man. 
 
 I guess you were unable to credibly document one of your reincarnation cases, and I still want to know where your "god" lives (city dweller?).

And just how merciful is it to spend 1,000 generations going through the hell people go through on earth?

 
 I take pity on your personal circumstances, EZ, but that's really another matter. A just and merciful God would be expected to give individuals more then one chance to get it right before consigning them to an eternity of damnation. Indeed, such a God would not be expected to dispatch anyone to such a fate. I give you the following analogy: when my daughter was young, I would sometimes ask her to clean up her room. She would insist that she'd rather go out and play. I'd then suggest to her that, once she'd cleaned up her room, she'd be allowed to go out and play. She'd pout and fuss, but it eventually dawned on her that I would not allow her to go out and play until she cleaned up her room. We are God's children, EZ.
 
 
If reincarnation is supposed to breed better people over the eons by virtue of them attaining a higher level of understanding, compassion, etc., through Karma, then it isn't working.

 
 The student is advised to study the subject. And no, please don't quote to me from Christian fundamentalist websites concerning the subject of reincarnation.

A just and merciful God would be expected to give individuals more then one chance to get it right before consigning them to an eternity of damnation. Indeed, such a God would not be expected to dispatch anyone to such a fate.

 
 Got a flash for you - The God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob gives people a whole lifetime of second, third, and fourth chances. He even goes out of his way to devise means so that a banished person might not remain estranged from him (2 Samuel 14:14).
 
 
We are God's children, EZ.

 
 Would that include Hitler and Osama bin Laden and other murdering thugs too?
 
 "He who has the Son (Christ) has life; he who does not have the Son does not have everlasting life but the wrath of God abides on him." John 3:36
 
 Today is the day of grace. Don't keep blowing it. God would rather you be saved in Christ.
 
 
And no, please don't quote to me from Christian fundamentalist websites concerning the subject of reincarnation. 

 
 You prefer revisionist liberal websites, I know. But seeing as how you're such a big Google fan, feel free to show me where I supposedly quoted from.

Got a flash for you - The God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob gives people a whole lifetime of second, third, and fourth chances.

 
 So, your god gives people the opportunity to go around once, after which it's either Harp City or the Lake-O-Fire for eternity? What does that say about your god's sense of mercy or justice as compared to, say, a god who lets you go around as many times as it takes for you to gain redemption? 
 
 
He even goes out of his way to devise means so that a banished person might not remain estranged from him (2 Samuel 14:14).

Would that include Hitler and Osama bin Laden and other murdering thugs too?

Do you really want to open this particular can of worms, EZ?

Are you asking me if I believe that individuals such as these would be given another chance to go around and redeem themselves? Yes, I think they would.

Where is the love of God there for humanity, and where is justice?

Originally posted by Orion: The concept of reincarnation makes more sense to me than the Christian notion wherein you go around once after which you face either eternal bliss or eternal damnation. It seems to me that such a notion violates two of the attributes which we generally ascribe to God, namely, mercy and justice.
 
 I won't get into a discussion about reincarnation except to say that there is not even the slightest shred of evidence to say that this is true. The only way that it could be true is if we could prove that the holy books of those religions (or just one religion) who believe in reincarnation (e.g. Hinduism) is actually divinely inspired. This can be proved beyond a reasonable doubt by examining accurate lines of scientific, historic, and prophetic verses in that holy book. The Bible contains all of these and other characteristics (such as it's civilising and life changing words). As such, if the Bible is true, then we can conclude that the whole concept (or belief) of reincarnation is false. To date, I am unaware of any such accurate verses in any holy book that tells people to believe in reincarnation.
 
 Does eternal suffering in hell for people who reject Jesus Christ as their LORD and Saviour contradict God's mercy and justice? Actually it does not! To understand the answer we need to go back to the beginning when Adam and Eve first rebelled against God. Through their actions, they were saying to God that they wanted nothing to do Him and that man wanted to decide truth independently of God. God, as the rightful and just judge, had to judge sin with death (which He warned Adam and Eve that He would).
 
 I was doing a google define search on the word "mercy" when I came across this:
 Mercy is the act of not administering justice when that justice is punitive. Because of our sinfulness we deserve death and eternal separation from God (Rom. 6:23; Isa. 59:2), but God provided an atonement for sin and through it shows us mercy. That is, He does not deliver to the Christian the natural consequence of his sin which is damnation [NL: the punishment for sin = death (from Genesis)]. That is why Jesus became sin on our behalf (2 Cor. 5:21) and bore the punishment due to us (Is. 53:4-5). It was to deliver us from damnation. (Compare with justice and grace.) God saved us according to His mercy (Titus 3:5) and we can practice mercy as a gift (Rom. 12:8). "Let us therefore draw near with confidence to the throne of grace, that we may receive mercy and may find grace to help in time of need" (Heb. 4:16).
 
 Of course, if we don't want to acknowledge that Jesus Christ is our Saviour (by doing so we are holding on to our sins), then we are saying through our actions and thoughts that we want nothing to do with God. God will grant us our wish and remove us from His presence. This is why Jesus will say to all the evil doers when He returns, "Depart from Me". God's justice will shine through here when we chose to hold on to our sins, we will get what we deserve and what they asked for, i.e. eternal suffering. However, if people repent from their sins, then God's mercy will fall down on them like rain (Jesus bore their punishment on the cross) and they will reside forever in Glory with Him. 
 
 Nu Leader.

I won't get into a discussion about reincarnation except to say that there is not even the slightest shred of evidence to say that this is true.The only way that it could be true is if we could prove that the holy books of those religions (or just one religion) who believe in reincarnation (e.g. Hinduism) is actually divinely inspired.

 
 Religous philosophy does not involve an attempt to establish evidence, truth, or proof. BTW, the concept of reincarnation is not limited to the Hindus. We find mention of this belief within Buddhism as well within ancient Greek and Persian societies. 
 
 
As such, if the Bible is true, then we can conclude that the whole concept (or belief) of reincarnation is false.

 
 You can neither 'prove' that the Judeo-Christian Bible is 'true' nor can you 'prove' that the concept of reincarnation is 'false'. Sorry. 
 
 
Does eternal suffering in hell for people who reject Jesus Christ as their LORD and Saviour contradict God's mercy and justice? Actually it does not!

 
 Actually, it does, from a logical perspective. If someone cannot, in good conscience, accept Jesus, does that someone then deserve, in your opinion, an eternity in the 'lake-o-fire'? Would that include Jews who went to their deaths in the concentration camps professing their belief in the God of Judaism? Be careful where you tread, my little friend. 
 
 
Of course, if we don't want to acknowledge that Jesus Christ is our Saviour (by doing so we are holding on to our sins), then we are saying through our actions and thoughts that we want nothing to do with God.

 
 Can you at least consider the possibility that billions of people do not equate Jesus with God but who nevertheless worship God, and that their position is as least as valid as your exclusivist theology? Can you further accept the possibility that God's grace extends even to those people who happen not to believe in his existence? To this last point, I refer you to the biblical parable of the Good Samaritan. Please consider the implications of that parable. I'd be happy to discuss those implications with you.
